On Mon, Jun 10, 2013 at 5:11 PM, Marcus = Blankenship <marcus@creoagency.com> wrote:
Show me money, and more importantly, sh= ow me profit per job.

Show me the profitability per= job, based on actual costs & revenue earned.  Make it about profi= t, and I'm sold.  

We're doing job costing reports by hand now, and while = they are a lot of work, they are very useful.  Just my $0.02.


On Jun 10, 2013, at 1= :36 PM, Brennan Dunn <brennan@planscope.io> wrote:

Hey guys,

I'm spending the sum= mer really doubling down on Planscope, and adding more features that a lot = of team accounts have asked for. I think Planscope has a competitive advant= age in that 1) we have workload + complexity data for each account and 2) w= e have integrated time tracking, and can cross compare estimates vs. actual= time logged.

With this in mind, I'm going to be rolling out a lot of= predictive and forecasting elements to the software. I'd like to use the d= ata I'm collecting to help teams make decisions and get insights that might= not be immediately obvious. A few scenarios come to mind:
  • Use estimated time vs. actual time to "handicap" estimates and= progress percentages
  • Use time log data to showcase resource alloca= tion and help predict who has future availability

The benefit for me is that older accounts allow for be= tter, more accurate prediction, which should help keep customers from cance= ling :-)

So my question to YOU...If you could q= uickly see a few key metrics and states related to your business, what woul= d they be? 

Here's a screenshot of a mockup I put together (don't m= ind the wildly inaccurate dates): https://www.dropbox.com/s/t3dh= hsv0yh85ctw/dashboard.jpg

Based on my wishlist when running Titans, I'm intereste= d in knowing...
  • What's the state of each of our projects?= When should each be wrapped up?
  • Who's working on what?
  • How much have we billed today, this week, and this year? How does this = compare to a week ago, a month ago, or a year ago?
  • What projects ar= e coming up? When? And who's scheduled?
  • What proposals are out in t= he wild?

I've incorporated #1, #2 and #3 into the cur= rent mockup, and will be displaying #3 and #5 in the right sidebar.

Any recommendations or overall thoughts?

Cheers,
Brennan

all.subject: Re: [30x500] 1st Ebomb - How to Hire the Top 1% of Outsourcers - feedback appreciated!
all.body:
Hi Nick, I think your ebomb contains some well-written, useful advice. The length seems great; long enough to get into some details, but not overly verbose. I did note a couple things while reading it that might be helpful for you to know about, or might just be me. The first thing that popped to my attention is your blog headline "Automate your business and watch it grow without hiring another employee." is immediately followed by your article title "How to hire the top 1% of outsourcers". I'm wasn't sure what this article would be about anymore, because it seems to be about not hiring people, and then hiring people. The article equates hiring "outsourcers" with hiring a VA. Is that the only kind of outsourcing people do? I thought this article might be relevant to outsourcing software development from the title, but it doesn't seem to be what you're going for. I'm also confused by the term "oursourcer". "outsourcer" implies to me a person or organization who procures resources from outside of the country. This article seems like it uses "outsourcer" to refer to the procured person, not the procuring person. Is that just my lack of familiarity with the correct jargon? :-) Mathieu On Mon, Jun 10, 2013 at 2:18 PM, Nick Karrasch wrote: > Hey all, > > Here's my first ebomb: > http://42insights.com/how-to-hire-the-best-outsourcers/. I'd really > appreciate any feedback, advice or comments people have, even if it's just > 1 sentence. > > It's not really public yet as there's no link to my blog from my homepage. > > Also, what do people think about splitting an ebomb into 2 separate posts? > Is it ok to do or would I be better off just having 1 gigantic post that is > 2-3x the length of this one? > > Thanks for any advice. > > *Nick Karrasch > *778 986 9498 > http://42insights.com > http://www.linkedin.com/in/nickkarrasch > > 312-235 E 13th St > North Vancouver, BC V7L 2L6 > Canada > > -- > You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups > "30x500 - Alumni" group. > To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an > email to 30x500-alumni+unsubscribe@googlegroups.com. > For more options, visit https://groups.google.com/groups/opt_out. > > > -- You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups "30x500 - Alumni" group.   • How much have we billed today, this week, and this year? How does this = compare to a week ago, a month ago, or a year ago?
  • What projects ar= e coming up? When? And who's scheduled?
  • What proposals are out = in the wild?

I've incorporated #1, #2 and #3 into the= current mockup, and will be displaying #3 and #5 in the right sidebar.

Any recommendations or overall thoughts?

Cheers,
Brennan

On Jun 10, 2013, at 4:01 PM, Brennan Dunn= <brennan@plan= scope.io> wrote:

This is a really, really = great thread. Kudos for kicking it off Nick!

I somet= imes think about whether I should have stayed a freelancer and bootstrapped= products much earlier than I actually did. Let's face it: If you'r= e billing $150ish an hour and working from home with very minimal overhead,= there's no reason you shouldn't be able to spend half your week on= bootstrapping and still live very comfortably.

But that's not the route I choose. I went the freel= ancer -> consultancy owner route, and was able to spend 3-4 months build= ing Planscope, and then a few months launching Planscope while others foote= d the bills. Though as glamorous as that might seem, I still had to actuall= y run the company. I was constantly interrupted to meet with clients, plan = BD with Zack, etc.

However, running a consultancy gave me such a large amo= unt of insight into various types of projects, products, and people in a co= mparatively short amount of time that I think it gave me more confidence an= d knowhow when it came to kicking off my own products. And since my product= s tend to target consultants, it helps having that sort of experience under= my belt.

But I think if you're solo now and want to cash out= by building your own SaaS app, I'd carve out a niche, launch it, and w= ork to get your first few customers. Realize you're about to start clim= bing the "slow, long SaaS ramp of death" and really start balanci= ng your time between your products and your clients. Schedule time each wee= k to plug away at marketing and talking with your customers (most important= ) and feature development (least important) and watch your growth slowly an= d steadily inch up.=A0

It's going to suck for the first year or two, but e= ventually you'll be able to start reducing your client workload because= your products making more and more money, and before you know it you'l= l realize, "Wow! I don't really need any more clients...."

And how I'd recommend exiting consulting :-)

On 7 Jun 2013, at 17:58, Blair Wadman <blair@wadmanconsulting.com> wrote:

Agreed.

Ironically, one of the best things to come out of the Consultancy=20 Masterclass is the realisation that I don't actually want to build a=20 consultancy. I had already decided to try and convert to a products=20 business and thought that building a consultancy might help with that.=20 But I have realised that it is just diverting my attention away from=20 what I really need to be focusing on. So I'll continue to be a one man= =20 consultancy and dedicate real time to the product side.

<postbox-contact.= jpg>
Nicholas Hance
=20 7 June 2013 14:2= 8
Hey Guys:

I wanted to share this with you.

Last week,=20 after BaconBizConf I had a chance to sit down and talk to one of the=20 founders of thoughtbot for a few hours. For those of you who aren't=20 familiar with that company, they're a consultancy with over 50 employee= s and several locations spread around the world.

Before I met him and had a chance to talk, I thought that they were a great target for where I want to take my consultancy.=20 After my talk, I'm not so sure.

The reason for= =20 this has to do with the way consultancies are valued in the marketplace. You see, a consultancy is worth only 1-2 years of your last year's=20 revenue, and that's only if you come with it.

So this means as we grow our business, we're going= =20 to do two things:

1. We're going to extract=20 money out of our businesses without worry. Keeping money in the business does not increase the value, so we'll enjoy what we've earned. (Or= use=20 it to fund your products.)

2. We're going to look for ways to build assets tha= t can be worth more than our last year's revenue. This is the only "= ;safe" investment we can make with the teams we're building.

If you aren't already thinking about building=20 products, or thinking of ways that you will be able to build a business=20 worth more than last year's results, you will be. You'll grow to a = point where you can't avoid thinking about this.

The biggest asset we have in our consultancies is=20 access and control of our awesome team, but if we aren't clients of our= =20 own consultancies we're going to miss the biggest opportunity we have= =20 for really securing our future.

Nick

P.S. Not that growing a team and the consultancy can't be worth it. You could make $1mill+ a= =20 year on a team size of 15 or so, but how can you retire if you can't=20 escape and still make the same amounts?

all.subject: Re: Why you'll stop consulting and build products someday
all.body:
Hey everyone - I know that a lot of you are interested in creating products, and some of you know that I've done a lot of consulting in the information product space - with price-points all across the board - ranging from $97 to $12k - and everything from ebooks, webinars, video, coaching and live events. Among my clients, I do some consulting with David Siteman Garland from The Rise To The Top (he interviews entrepreneurs - think similar to Andrew Warner and Mixergy) and David is just starting his product launch for the "Create Awesome Online Courses" - which is a course on how to create a course. I remember back in the early days - when all of this was just an idea - and it has been a lot of fun to consult with him along the way - and now to have it fleshed out into awesome content that suits his audience. It's geared toward people that already have a list and a following - so it's not a 100% fit for this list. Earlier today - David and I were on a call - and I mentioned the consultancy group - and asked him if a bunch of the members were interested - if I could sweet talk him into doing a special webinar for that group - or something like that - and David said that he'd think about it after launch when it quiets down. So he gave me an affiliate link -to use for tracking - to see if there's a group that's interested. I can't make promises - but here's the link if it's something that you're interested in. therise.ontraport.net/t?orid=680&opid=3 and yes, if you sign up, he's going to add you to the email list and send you the "VIP launch email and video sequence". I've seen the launch sequence - and there is some really good solid free material in it - so if you are interested - it's worth the email to get the free stuff (as well as you can save the email/video sequence as a swipe campaign. Swipe files make it so much faster when you're ready to create your own material - you wouldn't believe the difference and the time savings. I can't tell you how many of the campaigns that I've done with Ramit Sethi's products - that started out as a permutation of another campaign (his or someone else's) - and the same goes for the sales pages. It's one of those things that everyone doesn't always talk about openly - and it's a tactic that is a huge time saver. Hope that you enjoy it as a resource! For more options, visit https://groups.google.com/groups/opt_out. --20cf307ca1e6fb118204ded3b8c4 Content-Type: text/html; charset=ISO-8859-1 Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable Hey everyone - I know that a lot of you are interested in creating products= , and some of you know that I've done a lot of consulting in the inform= ation product space - with price-points all across the board - ranging from= $97 to $12k - and everything from ebooks, webinars, video, coaching and li= ve events. =A0

Among my clients, I do some consulting with David Siteman Ga= rland from The Rise To The Top (he interviews entrepreneurs - think=A0simil= ar=A0to Andrew Warner and Mixergy) and David is just starting his product l= aunch for the =A0"Create Awesome Online Courses" - which is a cou= rse on how to create a course. =A0I remember back in =A0the early days - wh= en all of this was just an idea - and it has been a lot of fun to consult w= ith him along the way - and now to have it fleshed out into awesome content= that suits his audience. =A0It's geared toward people that already hav= e a list and a following - so it's not a 100% fit for this list. =A0

Earlier today - David and I were on a call - and I ment= ioned the=A0consultancy=A0group - and asked him if a bunch of the members w= ere interested - if I could sweet talk him into doing a special webinar for= that group - or something like that - and David said that he'd think a= bout it after launch when it quiets down. =A0So he gave me an=A0affiliate= =A0link -to use for tracking - to see if there's a group that's int= erested. =A0I can't make promises - but here's the link if it's= something that you're interested in. =A0therise.ontraport.net/t?orid=3D680&opid=3D3=A0 and ye= s, if you sign up, he's going to add you to the email list and send you= the "VIP launch email and video sequence".

I've seen the launch sequence - and there is some r= eally good solid free material in it - so if you are interested - it's = worth the email to get the free stuff (as well as you can save the email/vi= deo sequence as a swipe campaign. =A0 =A0Swipe files make it so much faster= when you're ready to create your own material - you wouldn't belie= ve the difference and the time savings. =A0 I can't tell you how many o= f the campaigns that I've done with Ramit Sethi's products - that s= tarted out as a permutation of another campaign (his or someone else's)= - and the same goes for the sales pages. =A0 It's one of those things = that everyone doesn't always talk about openly - and it's a tactic = that is a huge time saver.

Hope that you enjoy it as a resource!

Rachel

I'm = just catching up on some of the email from last week and I have to agree wi= th Brennan. This is a wake up call for me. The problem is that I am not a p= rogrammer. I was recently challenged by a good friend to learn Rails. He is= an accomplished Rails Dev and suggested I give it a try. He was willing to= assist as were 2 other folks. It's been a month now and I have not mad= e any progress. We've been busy but if I am honest I have not given it = an ounce of effort. Part of me is scared and the other part is lazy. I need= to find new parts :)

In all seriousness though, this email thread means I am sett= ing a new goal of starting to learn programming in some language. It is goi= ng to be a slow walk instead of a sprint to the goal but I need to move in = the right direction.=A0

Thanks Nick!

On Jun 10, 2013, at 4:01 PM, Brennan Dunn= <brennan@plan= scope.io> wrote:

This is a really, really = great thread. Kudos for kicking it off Nick!

I somet= imes think about whether I should have stayed a freelancer and bootstrapped= products much earlier than I actually did. Let's face it: If you'r= e billing $150ish an hour and working from home with very minimal overhead,= there's no reason you shouldn't be able to spend half your week on= bootstrapping and still live very comfortably.

But that's not the route I choose. I went the freel= ancer -> consultancy owner route, and was able to spend 3-4 months build= ing Planscope, and then a few months launching Planscope while others foote= d the bills. Though as glamorous as that might seem, I still had to actuall= y run the company. I was constantly interrupted to meet with clients, plan = BD with Zack, etc.

However, running a consultancy gave me such a large amo= unt of insight into various types of projects, products, and people in a co= mparatively short amount of time that I think it gave me more confidence an= d knowhow when it came to kicking off my own products. And since my product= s tend to target consultants, it helps having that sort of experience under= my belt.

But I think if you're solo now and want to cash out= by building your own SaaS app, I'd carve out a niche, launch it, and w= ork to get your first few customers. Realize you're about to start clim= bing the "slow, long SaaS ramp of death" and really start balanci= ng your time between your products and your clients. Schedule time each wee= k to plug away at marketing and talking with your customers (most important= ) and feature development (least important) and watch your growth slowly an= d steadily inch up.=A0

It's going to suck for the first year or two, but e= ventually you'll be able to start reducing your client workload because= your products making more and more money, and before you know it you'l= l realize, "Wow! I don't really need any more clients...."

And how I'd recommend exiting consulting :-)
<= div>
Cheers,
Brennan

On 7 Jun 2013, at 17:58, Blair Wadman <blair@wadmanconsulting.com> wrote:

Agreed.

Ironically, one of the best things to come out of the Consultancy=20 Masterclass is the realisation that I don't actually want to build a=20 consultancy. I had already decided to try and convert to a products=20 business and thought that building a consultancy might help with that.=20 But I have realised that it is just diverting my attention away from=20 what I really need to be focusing on. So I'll continue to be a one man= =20 consultancy and dedicate real time to the product side.

<postbox-contact.= jpg>
Nicholas Hance
=20 7 June 2013 14:2= 8
Hey Guys:

I wanted to share this with you.

Last week,=20 after BaconBizConf I had a chance to sit down and talk to one of the=20 founders of thoughtbot for a few hours. For those of you who aren't=20 familiar with that company, they're a consultancy with over 50 employee= s and several locations spread around the world.

Before I met him and had a chance to talk, I thought that they were a great target for where I want to take my consultancy.=20 After my talk, I'm not so sure.

The reason for= =20 this has to do with the way consultancies are valued in the marketplace. You see, a consultancy is worth only 1-2 years of your last year's=20 revenue, and that's only if you come with it.

So this means as we grow our business, we're going= =20 to do two things:

1. We're going to extract=20 money out of our businesses without worry. Keeping money in the business does not increase the value, so we'll enjoy what we've earned. (Or= use=20 it to fund your products.)

2. We're going to look for ways to build assets tha= t can be worth more than our last year's revenue. This is the only "= ;safe" investment we can make with the teams we're building.

If you aren't already thinking about building=20 products, or thinking of ways that you will be able to build a business=20 worth more than last year's results, you will be. You'll grow to a = point where you can't avoid thinking about this.

The biggest asset we have in our consultancies is=20 access and control of our awesome team, but if we aren't clients of our= =20 own consultancies we're going to miss the biggest opportunity we have= =20 for really securing our future.

Nick

P.S. Not that growing a team and the consultancy can't be worth it. You could make $1mill+ a= =20 year on a team size of 15 or so, but how can you retire if you can't=20 escape and still make the same amounts?
--
Nicholas Hance

Among my clients, I do some consulting with David Siteman Ga= rland from The Rise To The Top (he interviews entrepreneurs - think=A0simil= ar=A0to Andrew Warner and Mixergy) and David is just starting his product l= aunch for the =A0"Create Awesome Online Courses" - which is a cou= rse on how to create a course. =A0I remember back in =A0the early days - wh= en all of this was just an idea - and it has been a lot of fun to consult w= ith him along the way - and now to have it fleshed out into awesome content= that suits his audience. =A0It's geared toward people that already hav= e a list and a following - so it's not a 100% fit for this list. =A0

Earlier today - David and I were on a call - and I ment= ioned the=A0consultancy=A0group - and asked him if a bunch of the members w= ere interested - if I could sweet talk him into doing a special webinar for= that group - or something like that - and David said that he'd think a= bout it after launch when it quiets down. =A0So he gave me an=A0affiliate= =A0link -to use for tracking - to see if there's a group that's int= erested. =A0I can't make promises - but here's the link if it's= something that you're interested in. =A0therise.ontraport.ne= t/t?orid=3D680&opid=3D3=A0 and yes, if you sign up, he's going = to add you to the email list and send you the "VIP launch email and vi= deo sequence".

I've seen the launch sequence - and there is some r= eally good solid free material in it - so if you are interested - it's = worth the email to get the free stuff (as well as you can save the email/vi= deo sequence as a swipe campaign. =A0 =A0Swipe files make it so much faster= when you're ready to create your own material - you wouldn't belie= ve the difference and the time savings. =A0 I can't tell you how many o= f the campaigns that I've done with Ramit Sethi's products - that s= tarted out as a permutation of another campaign (his or someone else's)= - and the same goes for the sales pages. =A0 It's one of those things = that everyone doesn't always talk about openly - and it's a tactic = that is a huge time saver.

Hope that you enjoy it as a resource!

Rachel

<= div>On Jun 10, 2013, at 4:01 PM, Brennan Dunn <brennan@planscope.io> wrote:

This is a really, really = great thread. Kudos for kicking it off Nick!

I somet= imes think about whether I should have stayed a freelancer and bootstrapped= products much earlier than I actually did. Let's face it: If you'r= e billing $150ish an hour and working from home with very minimal overhead,= there's no reason you shouldn't be able to spend half your week on= bootstrapping and still live very comfortably.

But that's not the route I choose. I went the freel= ancer -> consultancy owner route, and was able to spend 3-4 months build= ing Planscope, and then a few months launching Planscope while others foote= d the bills. Though as glamorous as that might seem, I still had to actuall= y run the company. I was constantly interrupted to meet with clients, plan = BD with Zack, etc.

However, running a consultancy gave me such a large amo= unt of insight into various types of projects, products, and people in a co= mparatively short amount of time that I think it gave me more confidence an= d knowhow when it came to kicking off my own products. And since my product= s tend to target consultants, it helps having that sort of experience under= my belt.

But I think if you're solo now and want to cash out= by building your own SaaS app, I'd carve out a niche, launch it, and w= ork to get your first few customers. Realize you're about to start clim= bing the "slow, long SaaS ramp of death" and really start balanci= ng your time between your products and your clients. Schedule time each wee= k to plug away at marketing and talking with your customers (most important= ) and feature development (least important) and watch your growth slowly an= d steadily inch up.=A0

It's going to suck for the first year or two, but e= ventually you'll be able to start reducing your client workload because= your products making more and more money, and before you know it you'l= l realize, "Wow! I don't really need any more clients...."

And how I'd recommend exiting consulting :-)
<= div>
Cheers,
Brennan

On 7 Jun 2013, at 17:58, Blair Wadman <blair@wadmanconsulting.com> wrote:

Agreed.

Ironically, one of the best things to come out of the Consultancy=20 Masterclass is the realisation that I don't actually want to build a=20 consultancy. I had already decided to try and convert to a products=20 business and thought that building a consultancy might help with that.=20 But I have realised that it is just diverting my attention away from=20 what I really need to be focusing on. So I'll continue to be a one man= =20 consultancy and dedicate real time to the product side.

<postbox-contact.= jpg>
Nicholas Hance
=20 7 June 2013 14:2= 8
Hey Guys:

I wanted to share this with you.

Last week,=20 after BaconBizConf I had a chance to sit down and talk to one of the=20 founders of thoughtbot for a few hours. For those of you who aren't=20 familiar with that company, they're a consultancy with over 50 employee= s and several locations spread around the world.

Before I met him and had a chance to talk, I thought that they were a great target for where I want to take my consultancy.=20 After my talk, I'm not so sure.

The reason for= =20 this has to do with the way consultancies are valued in the marketplace. You see, a consultancy is worth only 1-2 years of your last year's=20 revenue, and that's only if you come with it.

So this means as we grow our business, we're going= =20 to do two things:

1. We're going to extract=20 money out of our businesses without worry. Keeping money in the business does not increase the value, so we'll enjoy what we've earned. (Or= use=20 it to fund your products.)

2. We're going to look for ways to build assets tha= t can be worth more than our last year's revenue. This is the only "= ;safe" investment we can make with the teams we're building.

If you aren't already thinking about building=20 products, or thinking of ways that you will be able to build a business=20 worth more than last year's results, you will be. You'll grow to a = point where you can't avoid thinking about this.

The biggest asset we have in our consultancies is=20 access and control of our awesome team, but if we aren't clients of our= =20 own consultancies we're going to miss the biggest opportunity we have= =20 for really securing our future.

Nick

P.S. Not that growing a team and the consultancy can't be worth it. You could make $1mill+ a= =20 year on a team size of 15 or so, but how can you retire if you can't=20 escape and still make the same amounts?

all.subject: Re: Why you'll stop consulting and build products someday
all.body:
This thread feels like a bomb going off in my brain. Randomtype is presently churning out work at a rate that is great for the pocket book but leaves us with virtually no down time to invest in products (I know that I actually do have time, just haven't made room for it yet). I remember Brennan saying that when he pushed out Planscope it wasn't good enough for him to build in his down time, it had to be blocked off efforts diverted to product development (which is exactly how we build products.. the logic holds). This brings me to the question... what is the threshold everyone is waiting for to jump from *consulting -> product(s)*? Are you waiting for $XXXX to pull the trigger? Are you waiting for the right team? The right idea? I ask these questions because I don't know my own answers and I'm hoping some of you can help shed a strategic light onto potential paths forward... for the entire group. Among my clients, I do some consulting with David Siteman Ga= rland from The Rise To The Top (he interviews entrepreneurs - think=A0simil= ar=A0to Andrew Warner and Mixergy) and David is just starting his product l= aunch for the =A0"Create Awesome Online Courses" - which is a cou= rse on how to create a course. =A0I remember back in =A0the early days - wh= en all of this was just an idea - and it has been a lot of fun to consult w= ith him along the way - and now to have it fleshed out into awesome content= that suits his audience. =A0It's geared toward people that already hav= e a list and a following - so it's not a 100% fit for this list. =A0

Earlier today - David and I were on a call - and I ment= ioned the=A0consultancy=A0group - and asked him if a bunch of the members w= ere interested - if I could sweet talk him into doing a special webinar for= that group - or something like that - and David said that he'd think a= bout it after launch when it quiets down. =A0So he gave me an=A0affiliate= =A0link -to use for tracking - to see if there's a group that's int= erested. =A0I can't make promises - but here's the link if it's= something that you're interested in. =A0therise.ontraport.ne= t/t?orid=3D680&opid=3D3=A0 and yes, if you sign up, he's going = to add you to the email list and send you the "VIP launch email and vi= deo sequence".

I've seen the launch sequence - and there is some r= eally good solid free material in it - so if you are interested - it's = worth the email to get the free stuff (as well as you can save the email/vi= deo sequence as a swipe campaign. =A0 =A0Swipe files make it so much faster= when you're ready to create your own material - you wouldn't belie= ve the difference and the time savings. =A0 I can't tell you how many o= f the campaigns that I've done with Ramit Sethi's products - that s= tarted out as a permutation of another campaign (his or someone else's)= - and the same goes for the sales pages. =A0 It's one of those things = that everyone doesn't always talk about openly - and it's a tactic = that is a huge time saver.

Hope that you enjoy it as a resource!

Rachel

<= div>On Jun 10, 2013, at 4:01 PM, Brennan Dunn <brennan@planscope.io> wrote:

This is a really, really = great thread. Kudos for kicking it off Nick!

I somet= imes think about whether I should have stayed a freelancer and bootstrapped= products much earlier than I actually did. Let's face it: If you'r= e billing $150ish an hour and working from home with very minimal overhead,= there's no reason you shouldn't be able to spend half your week on= bootstrapping and still live very comfortably.

But that's not the route I choose. I went the freel= ancer -> consultancy owner route, and was able to spend 3-4 months build= ing Planscope, and then a few months launching Planscope while others foote= d the bills. Though as glamorous as that might seem, I still had to actuall= y run the company. I was constantly interrupted to meet with clients, plan = BD with Zack, etc.

However, running a consultancy gave me such a large amo= unt of insight into various types of projects, products, and people in a co= mparatively short amount of time that I think it gave me more confidence an= d knowhow when it came to kicking off my own products. And since my product= s tend to target consultants, it helps having that sort of experience under= my belt.

But I think if you're solo now and want to cash out= by building your own SaaS app, I'd carve out a niche, launch it, and w= ork to get your first few customers. Realize you're about to start clim= bing the "slow, long SaaS ramp of death" and really start balanci= ng your time between your products and your clients. Schedule time each wee= k to plug away at marketing and talking with your customers (most important= ) and feature development (least important) and watch your growth slowly an= d steadily inch up.=A0

It's going to suck for the first year or two, but e= ventually you'll be able to start reducing your client workload because= your products making more and more money, and before you know it you'l= l realize, "Wow! I don't really need any more clients...."

And how I'd recommend exiting consulting :-)
<= div>
Cheers,
Brennan

Agreed.

Ironically, one of the best things to come out of the Consultancy=20 Masterclass is the realisation that I don't actually want to build a=20 consultancy. I had already decided to try and convert to a products=20 business and thought that building a consultancy might help with that.=20 But I have realised that it is just diverting my attention away from=20 what I really need to be focusing on. So I'll continue to be a one man= =20 consultancy and dedicate real time to the product side.

<postbox-contact.= jpg>
Nicholas Hance
=20 7 June 2013 14:2= 8
Hey Guys:

I wanted to share this with you.

Last week,=20 after BaconBizConf I had a chance to sit down and talk to one of the=20 founders of thoughtbot for a few hours. For those of you who aren't=20 familiar with that company, they're a consultancy with over 50 employee= s and several locations spread around the world.

Before I met him and had a chance to talk, I thought that they were a great target for where I want to take my consultancy.=20 After my talk, I'm not so sure.

The reason for= =20 this has to do with the way consultancies are valued in the marketplace. You see, a consultancy is worth only 1-2 years of your last year's=20 revenue, and that's only if you come with it.

So this means as we grow our business, we're going= =20 to do two things:

1. We're going to extract=20 money out of our businesses without worry. Keeping money in the business does not increase the value, so we'll enjoy what we've earned. (Or= use=20 it to fund your products.)

2. We're going to look for ways to build assets tha= t can be worth more than our last year's revenue. This is the only "= ;safe" investment we can make with the teams we're building.

If you aren't already thinking about building=20 products, or thinking of ways that you will be able to build a business=20 worth more than last year's results, you will be. You'll grow to a = point where you can't avoid thinking about this.

The biggest asset we have in our consultancies is=20 access and control of our awesome team, but if we aren't clients of our= =20 own consultancies we're going to miss the biggest opportunity we have= =20 for really securing our future.

Nick

P.S. Not that growing a team and the consultancy can't be worth it. You could make $1mill+ a= =20 year on a team size of 15 or so, but how can you retire if you can't=20 escape and still make the same amounts?

all.subject: Re: Why you'll stop consulting and build products someday
all.body:
I know that for me its definitely X/month figure, we (all 3 partners) all have families (2 kids each) and live in a not-very-cheap neighbourhood. And while financial situation is not the same, I personally can't afford to downgrade much (especially with the planned move to Berlin). That being said I do sometimes have a free time to invest into products, so the problem is not entirely time related. We tried several times in the past, but we can't pass the 'lets get it to launch' threshold with anything product worthy. We did launch a couple of free toy projects (see http://markupslicer.com and http://isratracker.com), but nothing worth doing product out of. That, and the fact that one of the partners believes we can not sell products ourselves, that we somehow need to partner with some business guy to do it (which I don't believe). so we re-evaluated our 'getting to products' strategy again about 1-2 months ago, and decided to try to scale the company by at least 50% before we get back to products, not sure if its the right strategy though. -- You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups "Consultancy Masterclass" group. all.subject: Re: Why you'll stop consulting and build products someday
all.body:
I've got a product I'm planning on launching this fall. It was born out of being approached to do a contract job. The pay for that job wasn't stellar, so I suggested I'd just build the thing as a product that I'd license to the client. That arrangement has worked quite well, and I basically got a resellable product that someone else footed a lot of the bill for. It also worked nicely, because since it was originally a contract job, I knew it was something that someone would at least pay something for. I personally am waiting to have at least a few team members before scaling into other products. If I do launch a product, I want to make sure I'm not the only person responsible for responding to emergencies. I've got a product I'm planning on launching this = fall. =A0It was born out of being approached to do a contract job. =A0The p= ay for that job wasn't stellar, so I suggested I'd just build the t= hing as a product that I'd license to the client. =A0That arrangement h= as worked quite well, and I basically got a resellable product that someone= else footed a lot of the bill for. =A0It also worked nicely, because since= it was originally a contract job, I knew it was something that someone wou= ld at least pay something for.

I personally am waiting to have at least a few team members = before scaling into other products. =A0If I do launch a product, I want to = make sure I'm not the only person responsible for responding to emergen= cies.


On Mon,= Jun 10, 2013 at 5:51 PM, Vitaly Kushner <vitaly@astrails.com> wrote:
I know that for me its defi= nitely X/month figure, we (all 3 partners) all have families (2 kids each) = and live in a not-very-cheap neighbourhood. And while financial situation i= s not the same, I personally can't afford to downgrade much (especially= with the planned move to Berlin).

That being said I do sometimes have a free time to invest into pro= ducts, so the problem is not entirely time related. We tried several times = in the past, but we can't pass the 'lets get it to launch' thre= shold with anything product worthy. We did launch a couple of free toy proj= ects (see http://mark= upslicer.com and h= ttp://isratracker.com), but nothing worth doing product out of.
That, and the fact that one of the partners believes we can not = sell products ourselves, that we somehow need to partner with some business= guy to do it (which I don't believe).

so we re-evaluated our 'getting to products' strategy again ab= out 1-2 months ago, and decided to try to scale the company by at least 50%= before we get back to products, not sure if its the right strategy though.=

all.body:
Now that's a way to build a consultancy from the ground up. I wonder if my wife will appreciate the ten person plan ! If i try Subcontracting to other agencies she might have a word of course ! Paul Brian 07540 456 115 paul@mikadosoftware.com @lifeisstillgood pbrian.mikadosoftware.com On 11 Jun 2013, at 00:35, "joelhooks@gmail.com" wrote: Marcus, http://lifehacker.com/how-i-taught-myself-to-code-in-eight-weeks-511615189is really spot on. If you'd ever like to chat about it, drop me a line. I think about learning programming all the time. We have 4 kids and homeschool, and they will all have at *least* basic coding skills by the time I send them out into the real world. On Jun 10, 2013, at 4:01 PM, Brennan Dunn= <brennan@plan= scope.io> wrote:

This is a really, really = great thread. Kudos for kicking it off Nick!

I somet= imes think about whether I should have stayed a freelancer and bootstrapped= products much earlier than I actually did. Let's face it: If you'r= e billing $150ish an hour and working from home with very minimal overhead,= there's no reason you shouldn't be able to spend half your week on= bootstrapping and still live very comfortably.

But that's not the route I choose. I went the freel= ancer -> consultancy owner route, and was able to spend 3-4 months build= ing Planscope, and then a few months launching Planscope while others foote= d the bills. Though as glamorous as that might seem, I still had to actuall= y run the company. I was constantly interrupted to meet with clients, plan = BD with Zack, etc.

However, running a consultancy gave me such a large amo= unt of insight into various types of projects, products, and people in a co= mparatively short amount of time that I think it gave me more confidence an= d knowhow when it came to kicking off my own products. And since my product= s tend to target consultants, it helps having that sort of experience under= my belt.

But I think if you're solo now and want to cash out= by building your own SaaS app, I'd carve out a niche, launch it, and w= ork to get your first few customers. Realize you're about to start clim= bing the "slow, long SaaS ramp of death" and really start balanci= ng your time between your products and your clients. Schedule time each wee= k to plug away at marketing and talking with your customers (most important= ) and feature development (least important) and watch your growth slowly an= d steadily inch up.=A0

It's going to suck for the first year or two, but e= ventually you'll be able to start reducing your client workload because= your products making more and more money, and before you know it you'l= l realize, "Wow! I don't really need any more clients...."

And how I'd recommend exiting consulting :-)

Cheers,
Brennan

On 7 Jun 2013, at 17:58, Blair Wadman <blair@wadmanconsulting.com> wrote:

Agreed.

Ironically, one of the best things to come out of the Consultancy=20 Masterclass is the realisation that I don't actually want to build a=20 consultancy. I had already decided to try and convert to a products=20 business and thought that building a consultancy might help with that.=20 But I have realised that it is just diverting my attention away from=20 what I really need to be focusing on. So I'll continue to be a one man= =20 consultancy and dedicate real time to the product side.

<postbox-contact.= jpg>
Nicholas Hance
=20 7 June 2013 14:2= 8
Hey Guys:

I wanted to share this with you.

Last week,=20 after BaconBizConf I had a chance to sit down and talk to one of the=20 founders of thoughtbot for a few hours. For those of you who aren't=20 familiar with that company, they're a consultancy with over 50 employee= s and several locations spread around the world.

Before I met him and had a chance to talk, I thought that they were a great target for where I want to take my consultancy.=20 After my talk, I'm not so sure.

The reason for= =20 this has to do with the way consultancies are valued in the marketplace. You see, a consultancy is worth only 1-2 years of your last year's=20 revenue, and that's only if you come with it.

So this means as we grow our business, we're going= =20 to do two things:

1. We're going to extract=20 money out of our businesses without worry. Keeping money in the business does not increase the value, so we'll enjoy what we've earned. (Or= use=20 it to fund your products.)

2. We're going to look for ways to build assets tha= t can be worth more than our last year's revenue. This is the only "= ;safe" investment we can make with the teams we're building.

If you aren't already thinking about building=20 products, or thinking of ways that you will be able to build a business=20 worth more than last year's results, you will be. You'll grow to a = point where you can't avoid thinking about this.

The biggest asset we have in our consultancies is=20 access and control of our awesome team, but if we aren't clients of our= =20 own consultancies we're going to miss the biggest opportunity we have= =20 for really securing our future.

Nick

P.S. Not that growing a team and the consultancy can't be worth it. You could make $1mill+ a= =20 year on a team size of 15 or so, but how can you retire if you can't=20 escape and still make the same amounts?
--
Nicholas Hance

<= div>On Jun 10, 2013, at 4:01 PM, Brennan Dunn <brennan@planscope.io> wrote:

This is a really, really = great thread. Kudos for kicking it off Nick!

I somet= imes think about whether I should have stayed a freelancer and bootstrapped= products much earlier than I actually did. Let's face it: If you'r= e billing $150ish an hour and working from home with very minimal overhead,= there's no reason you shouldn't be able to spend half your week on= bootstrapping and still live very comfortably.

But that's not the route I choose. I went the freel= ancer -> consultancy owner route, and was able to spend 3-4 months build= ing Planscope, and then a few months launching Planscope while others foote= d the bills. Though as glamorous as that might seem, I still had to actuall= y run the company. I was constantly interrupted to meet with clients, plan = BD with Zack, etc.

However, running a consultancy gave me such a large amo= unt of insight into various types of projects, products, and people in a co= mparatively short amount of time that I think it gave me more confidence an= d knowhow when it came to kicking off my own products. And since my product= s tend to target consultants, it helps having that sort of experience under= my belt.

But I think if you're solo now and want to cash out= by building your own SaaS app, I'd carve out a niche, launch it, and w= ork to get your first few customers. Realize you're about to start clim= bing the "slow, long SaaS ramp of death" and really start balanci= ng your time between your products and your clients. Schedule time each wee= k to plug away at marketing and talking with your customers (most important= ) and feature development (least important) and watch your growth slowly an= d steadily inch up.=A0

It's going to suck for the first year or two, but e= ventually you'll be able to start reducing your client workload because= your products making more and more money, and before you know it you'l= l realize, "Wow! I don't really need any more clients...."

And how I'd recommend exiting consulting :-)
<= div>
Cheers,
Brennan

On 7 Jun 2013, at 17:58, Blair Wadman <blair@wadmanconsulting.com> wrote:

Agreed.

Ironically, one of the best things to come out of the Consultancy=20 Masterclass is the realisation that I don't actually want to build a=20 consultancy. I had already decided to try and convert to a products=20 business and thought that building a consultancy might help with that.=20 But I have realised that it is just diverting my attention away from=20 what I really need to be focusing on. So I'll continue to be a one man= =20 consultancy and dedicate real time to the product side.

<postbox-contact.= jpg>
Nicholas Hance
=20 7 June 2013 14:2= 8
Hey Guys:

I wanted to share this with you.

Last week,=20 after BaconBizConf I had a chance to sit down and talk to one of the=20 founders of thoughtbot for a few hours. For those of you who aren't=20 familiar with that company, they're a consultancy with over 50 employee= s and several locations spread around the world.

Before I met him and had a chance to talk, I thought that they were a great target for where I want to take my consultancy.=20 After my talk, I'm not so sure.

The reason for= =20 this has to do with the way consultancies are valued in the marketplace. You see, a consultancy is worth only 1-2 years of your last year's=20 revenue, and that's only if you come with it.

So this means as we grow our business, we're going= =20 to do two things:

1. We're going to extract=20 money out of our businesses without worry. Keeping money in the business does not increase the value, so we'll enjoy what we've earned. (Or= use=20 it to fund your products.)

2. We're going to look for ways to build assets tha= t can be worth more than our last year's revenue. This is the only "= ;safe" investment we can make with the teams we're building.

If you aren't already thinking about building=20 products, or thinking of ways that you will be able to build a business=20 worth more than last year's results, you will be. You'll grow to a = point where you can't avoid thinking about this.

The biggest asset we have in our consultancies is=20 access and control of our awesome team, but if we aren't clients of our= =20 own consultancies we're going to miss the biggest opportunity we have= =20 for really securing our future.

Nick

P.S. Not that growing a team and the consultancy can't be worth it. You could make $1mill+ a= =20 year on a team size of 15 or so, but how can you retire if you can't=20 escape and still make the same amounts?
--

all.subject: Re: Why you'll stop consulting and build products someday
all.body:
Thanks Rachel, it will be interesting to see what emails I get from that! On Mon, Jun 10, 2013 at 3:46 PM, Rachel Kersten wrote: > Hey everyone - I know that a lot of you are interested in creating > products, and some of you know that I've done a lot of consulting in the > information product space - with price-points all across the board - > ranging from $97 to $12k - and everything from ebooks, webinars, video, > coaching and live events. > > Among my clients, I do some consulting with David Siteman Garland from The > Rise To The Top (he interviews entrepreneurs - think similar to Andrew > Warner and Mixergy) and David is just starting his product launch for the > "Create Awesome Online Courses" - which is a course on how to create a > course. I remember back in the early days - when all of this was just an > idea - and it has been a lot of fun to consult with him along the way - and > now to have it fleshed out into awesome content that suits his audience. > It's geared toward people that already have a list and a following - so > it's not a 100% fit for this list. > > Earlier today - David and I were on a call - and I mentioned > the consultancy group - and asked him if a bunch of the members were > interested - if I could sweet talk him into doing a special webinar for > that group - or something like that - and David said that he'd think about > it after launch when it quiets down. So he gave me an affiliate link -to > use for tracking - to see if there's a group that's interested. I can't > make promises - but here's the link if it's something that you're > interested in. therise.ontraport.net/t?orid=680&opid=3 and yes, if you > sign up, he's going to add you to the email list and send you the "VIP > launch email and video sequence". > > I've seen the launch sequence - and there is some really good solid free > material in it - so if you are interested - it's worth the email to get the > free stuff (as well as you can save the email/video sequence as a swipe > campaign. Swipe files make it so much faster when you're ready to create > your own material - you wouldn't believe the difference and the time > savings. I can't tell you how many of the campaigns that I've done with > Ramit Sethi's products - that started out as a permutation of another > campaign (his or someone else's) - and the same goes for the sales pages. > It's one of those things that everyone doesn't always talk about openly - > and it's a tactic that is a huge time saver. > > Hope that you enjoy it as a resource! > > Rachel > > > > > On Mon, Jun 10, 2013 at 4:09 PM, marcus@marcusneto.com < > marcus@marcusneto.com> wrote: > >> I'm just catching up on some of the email from last week and I have to >> agree with Brennan. On Mon, Jun 10, 2013 at 3:46 PM, Rachel Kersten <rachel@rachelker= sten.com> wrote:
Hey everyone - I know that a lot of you are = interested in creating products, and some of you know that I've done a = lot of consulting in the information product space - with price-points all = across the board - ranging from $97 to $12k - and everything from ebooks, w= ebinars, video, coaching and live events. =A0

Among my clients, I do some consulting with David Siteman Ga= rland from The Rise To The Top (he interviews entrepreneurs - think=A0simil= ar=A0to Andrew Warner and Mixergy) and David is just starting his product l= aunch for the =A0"Create Awesome Online Courses" - which is a cou= rse on how to create a course. =A0I remember back in =A0the early days - wh= en all of this was just an idea - and it has been a lot of fun to consult w= ith him along the way - and now to have it fleshed out into awesome content= that suits his audience. =A0It's geared toward people that already hav= e a list and a following - so it's not a 100% fit for this list. =A0

Earlier today - David and I were on a call - and I ment= ioned the=A0consultancy=A0group - and asked him if a bunch of the members w= ere interested - if I could sweet talk him into doing a special webinar for= that group - or something like that - and David said that he'd think a= bout it after launch when it quiets down. =A0So he gave me an=A0affiliate= =A0link -to use for tracking - to see if there's a group that's int= erested. =A0I can't make promises - but here's the link if it's= something that you're interested in. =A0therise.ontraport.ne= t/t?orid=3D680&opid=3D3=A0 and yes, if you sign up, he's going = to add you to the email list and send you the "VIP launch email and vi= deo sequence".

I've seen the launch sequence - and there is some r= eally good solid free material in it - so if you are interested - it's = worth the email to get the free stuff (as well as you can save the email/vi= deo sequence as a swipe campaign. =A0 =A0Swipe files make it so much faster= when you're ready to create your own material - you wouldn't belie= ve the difference and the time savings. =A0 I can't tell you how many o= f the campaigns that I've done with Ramit Sethi's products - that s= tarted out as a permutation of another campaign (his or someone else's)= - and the same goes for the sales pages. =A0 It's one of those things = that everyone doesn't always talk about openly - and it's a tactic = that is a huge time saver.

Hope that you enjoy it as a resource!

Rachel

<= div>On Jun 10, 2013, at 4:01 PM, Brennan Dunn <brennan@planscope.io> wrote:

This is a really, really = great thread. Kudos for kicking it off Nick!

I somet= imes think about whether I should have stayed a freelancer and bootstrapped= products much earlier than I actually did. Let's face it: If you'r= e billing $150ish an hour and working from home with very minimal overhead,= there's no reason you shouldn't be able to spend half your week on= bootstrapping and still live very comfortably.

But that's not the route I choose. I went the freel= ancer -> consultancy owner route, and was able to spend 3-4 months build= ing Planscope, and then a few months launching Planscope while others foote= d the bills. Though as glamorous as that might seem, I still had to actuall= y run the company. I was constantly interrupted to meet with clients, plan = BD with Zack, etc.

However, running a consultancy gave me such a large amo= unt of insight into various types of projects, products, and people in a co= mparatively short amount of time that I think it gave me more confidence an= d knowhow when it came to kicking off my own products. And since my product= s tend to target consultants, it helps having that sort of experience under= my belt.

But I think if you're solo now and want to cash out= by building your own SaaS app, I'd carve out a niche, launch it, and w= ork to get your first few customers. Realize you're about to start clim= bing the "slow, long SaaS ramp of death" and really start balanci= ng your time between your products and your clients. Schedule time each wee= k to plug away at marketing and talking with your customers (most important= ) and feature development (least important) and watch your growth slowly an= d steadily inch up.=A0

It's going to suck for the first year or two, but e= ventually you'll be able to start reducing your client workload because= your products making more and more money, and before you know it you'l= l realize, "Wow! I don't really need any more clients...."

And how I'd recommend exiting consulting :-)
<= div>
Cheers,
Brennan

On 7 Jun 2013, at 17:58, Blair Wadman <blair@wadmanconsulting.com> wrote:

Agreed.

Ironically, one of the best things to come out of the Consultancy=20 Masterclass is the realisation that I don't actually want to build a=20 consultancy. I had already decided to try and convert to a products=20 business and thought that building a consultancy might help with that.=20 But I have realised that it is just diverting my attention away from=20 what I really need to be focusing on. So I'll continue to be a one man= =20 consultancy and dedicate real time to the product side.

<postbox-contact.= jpg>
Nicholas Hance
=20 7 June 2013 14:2= 8
Hey Guys:

I wanted to share this with you.

Last week,=20 after BaconBizConf I had a chance to sit down and talk to one of the=20 founders of thoughtbot for a few hours. For those of you who aren't=20 familiar with that company, they're a consultancy with over 50 employee= s and several locations spread around the world.

Before I met him and had a chance to talk, I thought that they were a great target for where I want to take my consultancy.=20 After my talk, I'm not so sure.

The reason for= =20 this has to do with the way consultancies are valued in the marketplace. You see, a consultancy is worth only 1-2 years of your last year's=20 revenue, and that's only if you come with it.

So this means as we grow our business, we're going= =20 to do two things:

1. We're going to extract=20 money out of our businesses without worry. Keeping money in the business does not increase the value, so we'll enjoy what we've earned. (Or= use=20 it to fund your products.)

2. We're going to look for ways to build assets tha= t can be worth more than our last year's revenue. This is the only "= ;safe" investment we can make with the teams we're building.

If you aren't already thinking about building=20 products, or thinking of ways that you will be able to build a business=20 worth more than last year's results, you will be. You'll grow to a = point where you can't avoid thinking about this.

The biggest asset we have in our consultancies is=20 access and control of our awesome team, but if we aren't clients of our= =20 own consultancies we're going to miss the biggest opportunity we have= =20 for really securing our future.

Nick

P.S. Not that growing a team and the consultancy can't be worth it. You could make $1mill+ a= =20 year on a team size of 15 or so, but how can you retire if you can't=20 escape and still make the same amounts?

all.subject: Re: Why you'll stop consulting and build products someday
all.body:
Tamer, one of the good things about it is that you're in control. If you aren't getting the full price from the first customer you just need to make sure you have interest from others. Like any sales process you can't trust vague promises that "I know a guy who really wants this some time next month". The original customer might be a good source of referrals as long as you can prove that they really are interested. If you can get advance payment from a few customers you might have something good to work with. This is a really, really = great thread. Kudos for kicking it off Nick!

I somet= imes think about whether I should have stayed a freelancer and bootstrapped= products much earlier than I actually did. Let's face it: If you'r= e billing $150ish an hour and working from home with very minimal overhead,= there's no reason you shouldn't be able to spend half your week on= bootstrapping and still live very comfortably.

But that's not the route I choose. I went the freel= ancer -> consultancy owner route, and was able to spend 3-4 months build= ing Planscope, and then a few months launching Planscope while others foote= d the bills. Though as glamorous as that might seem, I still had to actuall= y run the company. I was constantly interrupted to meet with clients, plan = BD with Zack, etc.

However, running a consultancy gave me such a large amo= unt of insight into various types of projects, products, and people in a co= mparatively short amount of time that I think it gave me more confidence an= d knowhow when it came to kicking off my own products. And since my product= s tend to target consultants, it helps having that sort of experience under= my belt.

But I think if you're solo now and want to cash out= by building your own SaaS app, I'd carve out a niche, launch it, and w= ork to get your first few customers. Realize you're about to start clim= bing the "slow, long SaaS ramp of death" and really start balanci= ng your time between your products and your clients. Schedule time each wee= k to plug away at marketing and talking with your customers (most important= ) and feature development (least important) and watch your growth slowly an= d steadily inch up.=A0

It's going to suck for the first year or two, but e= ventually you'll be able to start reducing your client workload because= your products making more and more money, and before you know it you'l= l realize, "Wow! I don't really need any more clients...."

And how I'd recommend exiting consulting :-)
<= div>
Cheers,
Brennan

On 7 Jun 2013, at 17:58, Blair Wadman <blair@wadmanconsulting.com> wrote:

Agreed.

Ironically, one of the best things to come out of the Consultancy=20 Masterclass is the realisation that I don't actually want to build a=20 consultancy. I had already decided to try and convert to a products=20 business and thought that building a consultancy might help with that.=20 But I have realised that it is just diverting my attention away from=20 what I really need to be focusing on. So I'll continue to be a one man= =20 consultancy and dedicate real time to the product side.

<postbox-contact.= jpg>
Nicholas Hance
=20 7 June 2013 14:2= 8
Hey Guys:

I wanted to share this with you.

Last week,=20 after BaconBizConf I had a chance to sit down and talk to one of the=20 founders of thoughtbot for a few hours. For those of you who aren't=20 familiar with that company, they're a consultancy with over 50 employee= s and several locations spread around the world.

Before I met him and had a chance to talk, I thought that they were a great target for where I want to take my consultancy.=20 After my talk, I'm not so sure.

The reason for= =20 this has to do with the way consultancies are valued in the marketplace. You see, a consultancy is worth only 1-2 years of your last year's=20 revenue, and that's only if you come with it.

So this means as we grow our business, we're going= =20 to do two things:

1. We're going to extract=20 money out of our businesses without worry. Keeping money in the business does not increase the value, so we'll enjoy what we've earned. (Or= use=20 it to fund your products.)

2. We're going to look for ways to build assets tha= t can be worth more than our last year's revenue. This is the only "= ;safe" investment we can make with the teams we're building.

If you aren't already thinking about building=20 products, or thinking of ways that you will be able to build a business=20 worth more than last year's results, you will be. You'll grow to a = point where you can't avoid thinking about this.

The biggest asset we have in our consultancies is=20 access and control of our awesome team, but if we aren't clients of our= =20 own consultancies we're going to miss the biggest opportunity we have= =20 for really securing our future.

Nick

P.S. Not that growing a team and the consultancy can't be worth it. You could make $1mill+ a= =20 year on a team size of 15 or so, but how can you retire if you can't=20 escape and still make the same amounts?

On Jun 10, 2013, at 1:36 PM, Brennan Du= nn <brennan@pl= anscope.io> wrote:

Hey guys,

I'm spending the summer really doubling down= on Planscope, and adding more features that a lot of team accounts have as= ked for. I think Planscope has a competitive advantage in that 1) we have w= orkload + complexity data for each account and 2) we have integrated time t= racking, and can cross compare estimates vs. actual time logged.

With this in mind, I'm going to be rolling out a lot of= predictive and forecasting elements to the software. I'd like to use the d= ata I'm collecting to help teams make decisions and get insights that might= not be immediately obvious. A few scenarios come to mind:
  • Use estimated time vs. actual time to "handicap" estimates and= progress percentages
  • Use time log data to showcase resource alloca= tion and help predict who has future availability

The benefit for me is that older accounts allow for be= tter, more accurate prediction, which should help keep customers from cance= ling :-)

So my question to YOU...If you could q= uickly see a few key metrics and states related to your business, what woul= d they be? 

Here's a screenshot of a mockup I put together (don't m= ind the wildly inaccurate dates): https://www.dropbox.com/s/t3dh= hsv0yh85ctw/dashboard.jpg

Based on my wishlist when running Titans, I'm intereste= d in knowing...
  • What's the state of each of our projects?= When should each be wrapped up?
  • Who's working on what?
  • How much have we billed today, this week, and this year? How does this = compare to a week ago, a month ago, or a year ago?
  • What projects ar= e coming up? When? And who's scheduled?
  • What proposals are out in t= he wild?

I've incorporated #1, #2 and #3 into the cur= rent mockup, and will be displaying #3 and #5 in the right sidebar.

Any recommendations or overall thoughts?

Cheers,
Brennan

all.subject: Re: [30x500] Pitch Review: Automatic Web API Documentation Testing Tool/Service/Something
all.body:
Hi Mathieu, It looks like you've changed your audience a bit... I can't relate to this one like with your previous pitches. This is written from the support person's point of view, right? Is s/he able to do the purchase decisions? The support person did the documentation too, so this is targeted to small companies, but then... they have a separate dev team. So this is not for mini companies, where the founder might be the one doing the support? Also, the pains in the first chapter and the rest of the pitch seem to be slightly different. It's going from "customer's don't read documentation - we get unnecessary support calls" from "documents are out of date". -Jaana On 10 June 2013 18:53, Mathieu Fenniak wrote: > Hi all, > > In my ongoing Safari of Web API developers, one area that keeps coming up > is API documentation tools. I've found a specific, compelling pain that I > believe I can fix, and that has a lot of potential room for future > development. I'd love to hear some feedback on this pitch: > > Another support ticket about the Web API hits your inbox. Every time your > customers hit the tiniest speedbump while using the API, they're firing off > terse, annoyed e-mails, and they're reaching you. It's irritating; why > don't they just read the documentation? It covers this case. You're sure, > you wrote it six months ago, and it definitely answers this guy's question. > > "I tried that, but it didn't work." The documentation is out-of-date. > The enhancement team added a new required field to that operation about > four months ago, and ever since then the docs have been incorrect. You go > from irritated to anxious in a flash; what else snuck through without a doc > update? > > Imagine if you were aware when your API documentation became dated. As > long as you're tuned in, it's a quick job to update the docs whenever > they're incorrect. Customers be happy to find their answers in reliable > examples, tutorials, and reference material; you'd be happy that they > didn't have to contact you. You'd never have to explain, "Oooh, that's for > version 3, but I guess it doesn't work anymore." The sneaky dev team would > get caught red-handed when changes go into the product without doc updates. > > Welcome to the world of , the intelligent Web API > documentation system. You can use to test the contents of > your documentation against reality. Every time you update your > documentation, and every week (just in case), you'll get a notification > that your documentation was analyzed and verified against the services > you're writing about. In my ongoing Safari of Web API developers, one area that keeps = coming up is API documentation tools. =A0I've found a specific, compell= ing pain that I believe I can fix, and that has a lot of potential room for= future development. =A0I'd love to hear some feedback on this pitch:

Another support ticket about the Web API hits your inbox. = =A0Every time your customers hit the tiniest speedbump while using the API,= they're firing off terse, annoyed e-mails, and they're reaching yo= u. =A0It's irritating; why don't they just read the documentation? = =A0It covers this case. =A0You're sure, you wrote it six months ago, an= d it definitely answers this guy's question.

"I tried that, but it didn't work." =A0Th= e documentation is out-of-date. =A0The enhancement team added a new require= d field to that operation about four months ago, and ever since then the do= cs have been incorrect. =A0You go from irritated to anxious in a flash; wha= t else snuck through without a doc update?

Imagine if you were aware when your API documentation b= ecame dated. =A0As long as you're tuned in, it's a quick job to upd= ate the docs whenever they're incorrect. =A0Customers be happy to find = their answers in reliable examples, tutorials, and reference material; you&= #39;d be happy that they didn't have to contact you. =A0You'd never= have to explain, "Oooh, that's for version 3, but I guess it does= n't work anymore." =A0The sneaky dev team would get caught red-han= ded when changes go into the product without doc updates.

Welcome to the world of <product-name/>, the inte= lligent Web API documentation system. =A0You can use=A0<product-name/>= ;=A0to test the contents of your documentation against reality. =A0Every ti= me you update your documentation, and every week (just in case), you'll= get a notification that your documentation was analyzed and verified again= st the services you're writing about. =A0Broken documentation screams a= t you, "Fix me!", while minor compatible changes that would have = no impact upon your customers are ignored.
<= br>
Mathieu

Hi Nick, It's a nice ebomb with lots of useful information. I'm in the middle of publishing an ebomb series and I'm already against it. I feel that 30x500 principles and post series just don't fit together. My series is not as popular in WHs as my earlier posts and now I'm stuck delivering it - because I've promised. The mail open rates are lower too and I get less shares & feedback. Series and pain-killing is a hard combination. I took a nice pain, wrote a gigantic article, split it - and later on noticed that the pain had diluted badly. As ebomb's purpose is to draw people in, it's not effective to offer them the same pain/topic several times in a progression. Even though we are teaching, this is about selling (the articles), getting attention and making people act. From pain-killing point of view, series leaves the reader disappointed.
